Long-term Information Storage
•Must store large amounts of data
- some App need large size(reservation , bank )
2.  Information stored must survive the termination 
of the process using it
For many App (e.g., for databases), the information 
must be retained for long time
3. Multiple processes must be able to access the 
information concurrently
While a process  is running

•Files are logical units of information created by 
processes.
• A disk will usually contain thousands or even 
millions of them, each one independent of the 
others
3
 File System

•Files are managed by OS , how they are 
structured, named, accessed, used, protected, 
implemented.
•That part of the operating system dealing with 
files is known as the file system
•In the following pages we will look at files 
from the user’s point of view, that is, how they 
are used and what properties they have.
4

• It provides a way to store information on 
the disk and read it back later. 
•This must be done in such a way as to 
shield the user from the details of how and 
where the information is stored, and how 
the disks actually work.
5

•The exact rules for file naming is different from 
system to system, but all current operating 
systems allow strings of one to eight letters as 
legal file names.
           Thus andrea, bruce, and cathy are possible  
file names.
•Many file systems support names as long as 255 
characters.
6
1- File Naming

•Many operating systems support two-part 
file names, with the two parts separated by a
period, as in    prog.c.
•The part following the period is called the 
file extension and usually indicates 
something about the file.
7

•In MS-DOS, for example, file names are 1 
to 8 characters, plus an optional extension 
of 1 to 3 characters.
•In UNIX, the size of the extension, if any, is
up to the user, and a file may even have two
or more extensions, as in
                 homepage.html.zip .
8

9
File Naming
Typical file extensions.

2- File Structure
•Three kinds of files
–byte sequence
–record sequence
–tree

•The file in Fig. (a) is an unstructured sequence of 
bytes. In effect, the operating system does not 
know or care what is in the file. 
•All it sees are bytes.
• Any meaning must be imposed by user-level 
programs. 
•Both UNIX and Windows use this approach.
•The first step up in structure is illustrated in Fig. 
4-2(b). In this model, a file is a sequence of fixed-
length records.
11

•The third kind of file structure is shown in Fig. 4-
2(c). In this organization, a file consists of a tree of
records, not necessarily all the same length.
•each containing a key field in a fixed position in 
the record.
• The tree is sorted on the key field, to allow rapid 
searching for a particular key.
12

13
3- File Types
•Many operating systems support several types 
of files.
•UNIX and Windows, for example, have regular 
files and directories.
•Regular files are the ones that contain user 
information. All the files of Fig. 4-2 are regular 
files. Directories are system files for 
maintaining the structure of the file system.
•Regular files are generally either (ASCII files) 
or (binary files.)

•For example, in Fig. 4-3(a) we see a simple 
executable binary file taken from an early 
version of UNIX.
•It has five sections: header, text, data, 
relocation bits, and symbol table.
 header  :  (magic number)identifying the file as
an executable, the sizes of the various pieces of 
the file, the address at which execution starts, 
some flags
•The symbol table is used for debugging.
14

15
File Types
(a) An executable file

•Our second example of a binary file is an archive,
also from UNIX.
•It consists of a collection of library procedures 
(modules) compiled but not linked.
•Each one is prefaced by a header telling its name, 
creation date, owner, protection code, and size. 
Just as with the executable file, the module headers
are full of binary numbers.
16

17
   (b) An archive

4- File Access
•Sequential access
–read all bytes/records from the beginning
–cannot jump around, could rewind or back up
–convenient when medium was mag tape
•Random access
–bytes/records read in any order
–essential for data base systems
–read can be ...
•move file marker (seek), then read or ...
•read and then move file marker

•Every file has a name and its data. 
  In addition, all operating systems associate      
other information with each file, forexample, the
date and time the file was last modified and the 
file’s size.
•We will call these extra items the file’s 
attributes. Some people call them metadata.

Directories
•To keep track of files, file systems normally 
have directories or folders, which are 
themselves files.
•we will discuss directories, their organization, 
their properties, and the operations that can be
performed on them.
26

•The simplest form of directory system is 
having one directory containing all the files.
•Sometimes it is called the root directory.
•On early personal computers, this system 
was common, in part because there was 
only one user.
27
1- Single-Level Directory Systems

•The advantages of this scheme are its 
simplicity and the ability to locate files 
quickly.
•It is sometimes still used on simple 
embedded devices such as digital cameras 
and some portable music players.
28

29
Single-Level Directory Systems
•A single level directory system
–contains 4 files
–owned by 3 different people, A, B, and C

•for modern users with thousands of files, it 
would be impossible to find anything if all 
files were in a single directory.
•Consequently, a way is needed to group related
files together.
•What is needed is a hierarchy (i.e., a tree of 
directories). With this approach, there can be 
as many directories as are needed to group the 
files.
30

31
2- Two-level Directory Systems
Letters indicate owners of the directories and files

32
Hierarchical Directory Systems
A hierarchical directory system

•The ability for users to create an arbitrary 
number of subdirectories provides a powerful 
structuring tool for users to organize their 
work.
•For this reason, nearly all modern file systems 
are organized in this manner.
33

Path Names
•When the file system is organized as a directory 
tree, some way is needed for specifying file 
names.
•Two different methods are commonly used. 
•In the first method, each file is given an absolute 
path name consisting of the path from the root 
directory to the file.
•Absolute path names always start at the root
•directory and are unique.
34

•In UNIX the components of the path are 
separated by /. 
•In Windows the separator is \ . 
•In MULTICS it was >.
Windows          \usr\ast\mailbox
UNIX               /usr/ast/mailbox
MULTICS        >usr>ast>mailbox
35

•The other kind of name is the relative path 
name.
• This is used in conjunction with the concept of 
the working directory (also called the current 
directory).
•For example, if the current working directory is 
/usr/ast, then the file whose absolute path is 
/usr/ast/mailbox can be referenced simply as 
mailbox.
36

In other words, the UNIX command :
cp /usr/ast/mailbox    /usr/ast/mailbox.bak
and the command :
cp mailbox  mailbox.bak
do exactly the same thing if the working 
directory is /usr/ast.
37

38
A UNIX directory tree

•Most operating systems that support a hierarchical
directory system have two special entries in every
directory, ‘‘.’’ and ‘‘..’’, generally pronounced 
‘‘dot’’ and ‘‘dotdot.’’
•Dot refers to the current directory; dotdot refers to
its parent.
•For example: it can copy the file usr/lib/dictionary  
to usr/ast/ directory using the command:
       cp    ../lib/dictionary .
cp /usr/lib/dictionary /usr/ast/dictionary
39

40
Directory Operations
•Create
•Delete
•Opendir
•Closedir
•Readdir
•Rename
•Link
•Unlink

•Create. A directory is created. It is empty 
except for dot and dotdot,which are put there 
automatically by the system (or in a few 
cases, by the mkdir program).
•Delete. A directory is deleted. Only an empty
directory can be deleted. A directory 
containing only dot and dotdot is considered 
empty as these cannot be deleted.
41

•Opendir. Directories can be read. For 
example, to list all the files in a directory, a 
listing program opens the directory to read 
out the names of all the files it contains. 
Before a directory can be read, it must be 
opened, analogous to opening and reading a 
file.
•Closedir. When a directory has been read, it
should be closed to free up internal table 
space.
42

•Readdir. This call returns the next entry in 
an open directory.
•Rename. In many respects, directories are 
just like files and can be renamed the same 
way files can be.
•Link. Linking is a technique that allows a 
file to appear in more than one directory.
•Unlink. A directory entry is removed.
43

44
File System Implementation

•Users are concerned with how files are named, 
what operations are allowed on them, what the 
directory tree looks like, and similar interface 
issues.
•Implementors are interested in how files and 
directories are stored, how disk space is 
managed, and how to make everything work 
efficiently and reliably.
45

File-System Layout
•File systems are stored on disks.
•Most disks can be divided up into one or more 
partitions, with independent file systems on each 
partition.
•Sector 0 of the disk is called the MBR (Master 
Boot Record) and is used to boot the computer.
•The end of the MBR contains the partition table
gives the starting and ending addresses of each 
partition.
46

•Every partition starts with a boot block, even if
it does not contain a bootable operating system
.( it might contain one in the future).
•the layout of a disk partition varies a lot from 
file system to file system
47

48
File System Implementation
A possible file system layout

•information in the superblock includes a 
magic number to identify the file-system type, 
the number of blocks in the file system, and 
other key administrative information.
•free blocks (bitmap or a list of pointers).
•i-nodes, an array of data structures, one per 
file, telling all about the file.
49

•root directory (top of the file-system tree).
50

•Probably the most important issue in 
implementing file storage is keeping track of 
which disk blocks go with which file.
•Different Methods :
-Contiguous Allocation
-Linked List , Linked list with File Allocate
-I node
51

Contiguous Allocation
•The simplest allocation scheme is to store 
each file as a contiguous run of disk blocks.
52

53
Implementing Files (1)
(a) Contiguous allocation of disk space for 7 files
(b) State of the disk after files D and F  have been removed

Contiguous disk-space allocation has two significant
advantages:
•First: it is simple to implement, remembering two 
numbers: the disk address of the first block and the 
number of blocks in the file.
•Second: the read performance is excellent because 
the entire file can be read from the disk in a single 
operation. Only one seek is needed (to the first 
block).
54

•After that, no more seeks or rotational 
delays are needed, so data come in at the 
full bandwidth of the disk. 
•Thus contiguous allocation is simple to 
implement and has high performance.
55

• Unfortunately, contiguous allocation also has a 
very serious drawback: over the course of time, 
the disk becomes fragmented.
•the disk will fill up and it will become necessary 
to either compact the disk(expensive) or to 
reuse the free space in the holes.
•this scheme is not likely to lead to happy users. 
However, still used: on CD-ROMs.
56

57

Linked-List Allocation
•The first word of each block is used as a 
pointer to the next one. The rest of the block is
for data.
•every disk block can be used in this method.
•No space is lost to disk fragmentation .
58

59
Implementing Files (2)
Storing a file as a linked list of disk blocks

•straightforward, random access is extremely
slow.
•the amount of data storage in a block is no 
longer a power of two because the pointer 
takes up a few bytes.
60

61

Linked-List Allocation Using a 
Table in Memory
•Both disadvantages of the linked-list allocation 
can be eliminated by taking the pointer word 
from each disk block and putting it in a table in 
memory.
62

63
Implementing Files (3)
Linked list allocation using a file allocation table in RAM

•Both chains are terminated with a special marker
(e.g., −1) that is not a valid block number. 
•Such a table in main memory is called a FAT(
File Allocation Table).
•Using this organization, the entire block is 
available for data. Furthermore, random access 
is much easier.
•the chain is entirely in memory, so it can be 
followed without making any disk references.
64

•The primary disadvantage of this method is that 
the entire table must be in memory all the time to
make it work.
•Clearly the FAT idea does not scale well to large 
disks. 
•It was the original MS-DOS file system and is 
still fully supported by all versions of Windows 
though.
65

66

I-nodes
•Our last method  a data structure called an i
-node (index-node).
•which lists the attributes and disk addresses
of the file’s blocks.
67

68
Implementing Files (4)
An example i-node

69

•The  big  advantage  of  this  scheme  over
linked files using an in-memory table is that
the  i-node  need  be  in  memory  only  when
the corresponding file is open.
•the  i-node  scheme  requires  an  array  in
memory  whose  size  is suitable  to  the
maximum number of files that may be open
at once.
70

•One problem with i-nodes is that if each
one has room for a fixed number of disk
addresses,  what  happens  when  a  file
grows beyond this limit?
•One  solution  is  to  reserve  the  last  disk
address not for a data block, but instead
for  the  address  of  a  block  containing
more disk-block addresses.
71

•Similarly, the Windows NTFS file system
uses a similar idea.
72

Implementing Directories
•The directory entry provides the information 
needed to find the disk blocks.
•In all cases, the main function of the directory 
system is to map the ASCII name of the file onto 
the information needed to locate the data.
•A closely related issue is where the attributes 
should be stored.
73

74
Implementing Directories (1)
(a) A simple directory
fixed size entries
disk addresses and attributes in directory entry
(b) Directory in which each entry just refers to an i-node

•In MS-DOS files have a 1–8 character base 
name and extension of 1–3
•In UNIX Version 7, file names were 1–14 
characters, including any extensions.
•However, nearly all modern operating systems 
support longer, variable-length file names.
• How can these be implemented?
75

Shared files
79

•When  several  users  are  working  together  on  a
project, they often need to share files.
•As a result, it is often convenient for a shared file
to appear simultaneously in different directories
belonging to different users.
•In Fig. 4-7 The connection between B’s directory
and the shared file is called a link.
•The file system itself is now a Directed Acyclic 
Graph, or DAG, rather than a tree.
80

81
Shared Files (1)
File system containing a shared file

•Sharing files is convenient, but it also introduces 
some problems.(copy of the disk addresses will 
have to be made in B’s directory ).
•appends to the file, the new blocks will be listed 
only in the directory of the user doing the 
append. And The changes will not be visible to 
the other user.
82

This problem can be solved in two ways
•In the first, data structure associated with the file
itself.  (I-Node)
•In  the  second,  create  new  file  contains  just  the
path  name of  the  file  to  which  it  is  linked.  (
symbolic linking)
83

Each of these methods has its drawbacks:
•In  the  first  method,  i-node  records  the  file’s
owner as C, If C tries to remove the file.
•The  only  thing  to  do  is  remove C’s  directory
entry, but leave the i-node intact, with count set
to 1, as shown in Fig. 4-17(c).
•at which time the count goes to 0 and the file is
deleted.
84

85
Shared Files (2)
(a) Situation prior to linking
(b) After the link is created
(c)After the original owner removes the file

•With symbolic links this problem does not 
arise because only the true owner has a 
pointer to the i-node.
•Users who have linked to the file just have 
path names, not i-node pointers. When the 
owner removes the file, it is destroyed.
86

•The  problem  with  symbolic  links is  the  extra
overhead required.
•The file containing the path must be read, then
the  path  must  be parsed  and followed,
component  by  component,  until  the  i-node  is
reached.    All  of  this  activity  may  require  a
considerable number of extra disk accesses.
87
